q: What are the symptoms of heavy periods?
a: You may have heavy periods if you need to change your pad or tampon every 1 to 2 hours, have periods lasting more than 7 days, pass blood clots larger than about 2.5cm, or bleed through to your clothes or bedding.

q: What are the causes of heavy periods?
a: Heavy periods can be caused by conditions affecting your womb, ovaries, or hormones, such as polycystic ovary syndrome, fibroids, endometriosis, and pelvic inflammatory disease. They can also be caused by certain medications and treatments, stress, depression, or rarely, womb cancer.

q: When should I see a doctor about heavy periods?
a: You should see a doctor if your heavy periods are affecting your life, if you've had heavy periods for a while, if you experience severe pain during your periods, if you bleed between periods or after sex, or if you have heavy periods along with other symptoms like pain during urination, bowel movements, or sex.

q: How are heavy periods treated?
a: Treatments for heavy periods include certain types of contraception like an intrauterine system or combined contraceptive pill, medications to reduce bleeding like tranexamic acid, and prescription anti-inflammatory painkillers. If these treatments don't work or if a condition is suspected, your doctor may refer you for further tests or to see a specialist.

q: What can I do if I have heavy periods but don't want to take medication?
a: If you prefer not to take medication for heavy periods, you can try using alternative menstrual products like menstrual cups or period-proof underwear, practicing relaxation techniques or managing stress, maintaining a healthy diet and exercise routine, and discussing other non-medication options with your doctor.

q: Can heavy periods lead to anemia?
a: Yes, heavy periods can lead to iron deficiency anemia. It is recommended to have a blood test to check for anemia if you have heavy periods.
